body: As far as I can tell, scripts are considered to be part of the `.Commands` property as well. Scripts are added with `ps.Commands.AddScript(script)` the same way you can use `ps.AddScript(script)` and the entry is removed in both cases from `ps.Commands` when you call `ps.Commands.Clear()`

Just to add more info a script and command are represented by [Command](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.management.automation.runspaces.command?view=powershellsdk-7.0.0) and the only difference is a script has `IsScript -eq $true`. Just to verify

```powershell
$ps = [Powershell]::Create()
[void]$ps.AddScript('1')
$ps.Commands.Commands | Select *

# Parameters                           : {}
# CommandText                          : 1
# IsScript                             : True
# UseLocalScope                        : False
# CommandOrigin                        : Runspace
# IsEndOfStatement                     : False
# MergeUnclaimedPreviousCommandResults : None

[void]$ps.AddScript('2')
$ps.Commands.Commands | Select *

# Parameters                           : {}
# CommandText                          : 1
# IsScript                             : True
# UseLocalScope                        : False
# CommandOrigin                        : Runspace
# IsEndOfStatement                     : False
# MergeUnclaimedPreviousCommandResults : None

# Parameters                           : {}
# CommandText                          : 2
# IsScript                             : True
# UseLocalScope                        : False
# CommandOrigin                        : Runspace
# IsEndOfStatement                     : False
# MergeUnclaimedPreviousCommandResults : None

$ps.Commands.Clear()
[void]$ps.AddScript('3')
$ps.Commands.Commands | Select *

# Parameters                           : {}
# CommandText                          : 3
# IsScript                             : True
# UseLocalScope                        : False
# CommandOrigin                        : Runspace
# IsEndOfStatement                     : False
# MergeUnclaimedPreviousCommandResults : None
```

yep, just wrote some code to check this as well and indeed command.Clear also clears the scripts. The relationship between ps.Commands content and ps content was the point of confusion for me - I'd assumed the commands are for commands only and didn't look for scripts in there. @jborean93 comment clears it up, thanks.
